steps.title: Introduction
steps.text: In this puzzle we are exploring the effect of the "Finned X-Wing".

steps.title: First Steps
steps.text: We start on 2's. And get one easy number in box nine.
With that new 2 in box nine, we get another one in box eight.
Despite that there are a lot of 3's, they don't get us another digit.
On 6's we get an easy digit in the first row.
The 6 in box three forces a 6 to be in column eight of box nine (green triple). With that, there can't be another 6 in that column anymore. So there is only one place left in box six.
With these new 6's we get our final 6 for the moment in the center box.

steps.title: Almost full column
steps.text: The seventh column is almost complete, missing only a 7 and 9. With the 7 in row one we can now complete the column by first adding the 7 ...
... and finally putting in the missing 9.

steps.title: Spyder Notation
steps.text: We can do a bit of Snyder Notation. Though we will find a pair of 1's and 3's in the center box, we don't get another digit this way.
We can easily spot another pair of 1's in box one and three.
Moving on with 2's. An easy pair can be found in box four. The 1-3-pair in box five reduces the 2's to a pair.
In the center box the 1-3-pair again reduces 4's this time. The last pair of 4's for now is in box seven.
We can reduce 5's to a pair only in box eight and nine.
6's in box seven and eight.
The 8's of box four and nine create a pointing pair in box seven.
This pointing pair and the 8 from box five reduce the candidates in box eight to a pair.

steps.title: Weak Cells
steps.text: Weak cells "see" a lot of different digits. For example in row eight in box seven we extract the first half of a 7-9-pair.
And in box nine we discover the other half of it. That way we are reducing the remaining cells in row eight to a triple.

steps.title: The Finned X-Wing
steps.text: Let's focus on 1's, because we already found four of them and in three boxes they are limited to a pair. We have completed all pencil marks. Have a closer look at row two and six.
There we almost see an X-Wing. Those are called "Finned" X-Wings, if there are additional candidates on one of the edges.
The logic of the normal X-Wing would let us remove all remaining candidates of 1 between the edges.
But the fin (green) reduces the range of an X-Wing. So we can only remove those candidates, which are also seen by the fin.
A well constructed Sudoku often has a solution path. This is why it is always worth looking where you already found a special pattern. So let's keep looking at box six and column eight.

steps.title: Hidden Triple
steps.text: It is a bit hard to spot, but 4's and 8's have a big impact on column eight. The 4's in box six and nine reduce the candidates in column eight, so that 4's remain only in box three.
Now we check the 8's and see that there is a triple of 1's, 4's and 8's. This was made possible by the "Finned X-Wing".

steps.title: X-Wing
steps.text: As mentioned earlier, let's focus on the areas, where we made progress. Look at 3's now. Because the 3 in box nine and the newly found triple reduce the remaining 3's in box six to a pair.
The 3-pairs in box five and six form a nice standard "X-Wing". With that and the 3 from box seven we get our next digit in box four.

steps.title: Completing 2's
steps.text: In the same box we can witness one advantage of the "Snyder Notation". Here in box four is only one pencil mark of 2's left.
This means that the 2 can only be placed here. This 2 resolves the last digit in the center box. And the 2's are done.

steps.title: Skyscraper Options
steps.text: The sixth row is now almost complete. Because of the triple (green) in column eight, we can only put 9's in the first and last cell of this row (yellow).
The pair of 9's in row six plus the pair of 9's in row eight forming a pattern called skyscraper. A skyscraper consists of four cells forming a right trapezoid.
For the next step, let's find all candidates of 9's in boxes four and seven, but also in row seven to show that there are in fact two possible skyscrapers.
Of course you can use both skyscrapers to eliminate candidates, but in this puzzle it is not necessary, because either one cracks the puzzle open.

Let's have a look at the first skyscraper. The edges (blue) of the uneven side of that pattern are important. We look at 9's here. We can eliminate every candidate of 9's from every cell in the sudoku, which can see both uneven edges (blue) of the skyscraper.
The 9 in box nine and row seven is the last one in that row. With that new digit the rest of the puzzle is very straight forward.
